questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision in her right eye and the keratometry was done. Which of the following K values is the most appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pterygium causes decrease in vision due to either:

  • Astigmatism (With-the-rule astigmatism where the vertical meridian(90 degrees) is steep; seen as higher K value along 90 degrees)
  • Obscuration of the visual axis by encroaching into the pupillary area.

The pterygium in this patient has encroached into the pupillary area. This is most likely to produce visual disturbance by astigmatism.

Option C shows a higher K value(48.25D) along the vertical meridian(90 degrees) which means that the vertical meridian is steep: With-the-rule astigmatism. The horizontal meridian(180 degrees) is flat which is represented by the lower K value(43.50D)

In option B, there is no astigmatism as the K values in both the principal meridian are the same(44.00D)

questions.text: A 28 year old male sustained fracture of femur and is being treated. He suddenly complains of sudden bilateral painless decrease in vision. Fundus picture and his OCT are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Purtscher retinopathy

Purtscher retinopathy is  also known as traumatic retinal angiopathy, lymphorrhagia retinae, or retinal tele-traumatism.

It is an occlusive microvasculopathy and occurs following head or chest trauma

The characteristics of this retinopathy are huge juxtapapillary cottonwool spots and hemorrhages in the peri-papillary and the macular area up to the mid periphery

Patients with Purtscher retinopathy typically present with a sudden-onset painless visual decline in both eyes within two days of trauma.

Causes of Purtscher retinopathy:

  • Severe head trauma
  • Chest compression
  • Fracture of long bones (eg. femur) or crush injury
  • Barotrauma
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Embolism (fat, air, amniotic fluid)

Pathophysiology:

Leukoembolization, endothelial damage, activation of complement C5 and blockade of small arterioles causing infarct of the capillary bed have been implicated in the pathogenesis of Purtscher retinopathy and Purtscher-like retinopathy. C5a component of the complement predisposes to the aggregation of leukocytes (granulocytes) which embolize. These microemboli are very small (60 to 80 microns) and cause multiple small arteriolar occlusion

questions.text: Pseudo-Fleischer ring is seen in:
questions.solution: Epithelial iron deposition at the margin of the ablated zone, after hyperopic LASIK.

choices.text: Best treated with supramaximal LPS resection

questions.text: A52-year old female comes to the eye OPD with complaints of progressively droopy eyelids with no diurnal variation. On examination, there is global restriction of both eye movements. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is false?
questions.solution:
CPEO is characterised by slowly progressive bilateral limitation of eye movements in all directions and ptosis.

CPEO is a mitochondrial disease. Recently, mutations in three different genes, ANT1 (4q34-35), Twinkle (10q24) and POLG (15q22-26) have been.

Kearns–Sayre syndrome (KSS) is regarded as a specific and severe form of CPEO, with more signs of mitochondrial disease. Patients of KSS have cardiac conduction defects and pigmentary retinopathy.

The ptosis is best treated by tarso -frontalis sling - using silicone rods as they are adjustable. LPS resection is usually avoided due to the risk of exposure keratopathy secondary to poor Bell’s phenomenon in these patients.

questions.text: Images A and B show the pre-op and post-op appearances respectively of a 37-year old female patient. Wat procedure is most likely to have been performed?
questions.solution:
Image A shows bilateral lid retraction and superior scleral show – signs of thyroid eye disease.

In image B, this has been corrected by relaxing the LPS by recessing the muscle. Therefore, Option C

LPS resection is done for correcting ptosis

Fasanella Servat procedure is done for mild ptosis due to Horner’s syndrome

questions.text: This image shows:
questions.solution:
Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD) also known as Cogan’s epithelial dystrophy is the most common type of corneal dystrophy.

The pathophysiologic hallmark of EBMD is an abnormality in the formation and maintenance of the epithelial basement membrane adhesion complex of the corneal epithelium due to abnormal hemidesmosomes. This results in recurrent epithelial erosions.

With continued cycles of epithelial breakdown and aborted efforts at the development of a stable epithelial basement membrane adhesion complex, the classic 'map-dot-fingerprint' epithelial and subepithelial findings that characterize this disorder develop.

questions.text: A 7-year old boy was brought with complaints of decreased vision in the right eye. On cursory examination, there was leukocoria. Fundus examination was done and the image is shown below> What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Coats disease is an idiopathic retinal vascular disorder with retinal telangiectasia with intraretinal and/or subretinal exudation.

The condition is sporadic with no associated systemic abnormalities.

Unilateral involvement in young males is the typical presentation with most cases being diagnosed in the first and second decade of life.

Younger the patient, more severe is the presentation and poorer the visual outcome.

The gold standard for diagnosis of Coats disease is examination of the fundus by indirect ophthalmoscopy.

Retinal telangiectasia is found in all cases. These have been described as 'light bulb telangiectasias' because of the bulbous terminal configuration and associated extensive yellow exudation.

Most of the complications are secondary to chronic retinal detachment(exudative/serous type).

Treatment must be initiated if progression is noted. Laser photocoagulation is indicated in early Coats with exudation but no or shallow retinal detachment.

choices.text: Left oculomotor, left trochlear and right abducens nerves
Left oculomotor, left trochlear and left abducens nerves
Right oculomotor, left trochlear and left abducens nerves
Left oculomotor, right trochlear and left abducens nerves

questions.text: IN this patient, which of the following nerves are affected?
questions.solution: The lesion is probably in the left cavernous sinus

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of this 33-year old female patient whose CT is given below?
questions.solution:
Most common cause of bilateral proptosis in adults is Thyroid eye disease(TED)

TED is characterised by extraocular muscle enlargement with characteristic tendon sparing.

This CT shows bilateral proptosis and EOM enlargement(“coca-cola bottle” sign). The first muscle to be involved is IR followed by MR, then SR, LR, IO and SO(in that order) Mnemonic: I’M SLO

choices.text: Vitamin D deficiency accelerates the progression of diabetic retinopathy
Vitamin D's protective role in DR is mediated through calcitriol
Serum Vitamin D could be a biomarker for PDR development
Calcitriol downregulated VEGF by upregulating the activity of hypoxia?inducible factor?1 (HIF?1)

questions.text: In this patient with diabetic retinopathy, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D may also contribute to DR via angiogenesis mechanisms. Active metabolite of vitamin D, calcitriol, is a potent inhibitor of retinal neovascularization. Calcitriol also inhibits retinal endothelial cell capillary morphogenesis. Calcitriol downregulates hypoxia?inducible factor?1 (HIF?1) transcriptional activity and HIF?1 target genes, such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)

Complications in DR, such as macular edema and neovascularization, are driven by VEGF production. Vitamin D could exert its positive effect via calcitriol-mediated VEGF reduction.

Deficiency of vitamin D accelerates the severity of retinopathy. Serum vitamin D levels of ≤18.6 ng/mL were found to serve as sensitive and specific biomolecular biomarker for proliferative disease, among patients of DR.

RDA of 600?800 IU is recommended to maintain adequate levels of vitamin D. Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) recommends a daily supplement of 400 IU/day of vitamin D for Indians under situations of minimal exposure to sunlight.

choices.text: She is a confirmed case of keratoconus
She is a suspected case of keratoconus
The I-S value reflects superior steepening
Scissoring reflex would be seen on retinoscopy

questions.text: A 16-year old female visited the optician to get her glasses changed. The optometrist noticed an increase in astigmatism and referred to the ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management. Corneal topography was performed. The central Keratometry value was 47D and 46.8D respectively in her right and left eyes. I-S value was 1.6.Her KISA% values were 65 and 62 respectively. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
This is a patient with SUSPECTED KERATOCONUS

Scissoring reflex is seen in early case of keraoconus(when it has actually developed; not in suspected cases)

The Rabinowitz/Mc Donnel diagnostic criteria for keratoconus consists of two topography-derived indices, which are as follows:

  • Central K-value > 47.20 D and
  • Inferior-Superior asymmetry (I-S value) > 1.4 D

Inferior-Superior Value (I-S): This index is defined as the power difference between five points of the inferior hemisphere and five points of the superior hemisphere of the cornea. A positive value indicates higher inferior curvature while a negative value indicates higher superior curvature. I-S values between 1.4 and 1.8 D are defined as cut-off points for suspected keratoconus and I-S values higher than 1.8 D as cut-off points for clinical keratoconus

KISA%: It is calculated from four indices:

  1. Central K
  2. SIMK
  3. I - S and
  4. SRAX

It is a very effective index in the identification of keratoconus. A value between 60 and 100 is indicative of suspected keratoconus, while a value greater than 100 is diagnostic of keratoconus; for this last value the KISA index has a high sensitivity and specificity

questions.text: Enlarged blind spot is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Disc edema produces enlarged blind spot on perimetry.

Disc edema is found in options a and c. Papillophlebitis is unilateral while IIH is bilateral.

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) in young adults in commonly referred to as papillophlebitis. This rare disorder is usually unilateral, found more often in males with a predilection towards hyperopic patients. The ocular manifestations of papillophlebitis include disc edema alone, or disc edema accompanied by venous dilation and tortuosity. It is idiopathic although the patient should be worked up for contributing factors, which can include HTN, DM, hyperlipidemia and hypercoagulability.

In glaucoma, sickle-shaped Seidel’s scotoma is seen on perimetry. This is considered as enlarged blind spot.

questions.text: This 54-year old male diabetic patient presented with decrease in vision in his right eye. What is the standard of care treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of CRVO - central retinal vein occlusion. The most common cause for decrease in vision in CRVO is macular edema.

The rationale for anti-VEGF therapy of macular edema following RVO is based on the observation that intraretinal VEGF mRNA transcription and intraocular VEGF levels were increased in patients with RVO compared with a control group. VEGF increases vessel permeability by increasing the phosphorylation of tight junction proteins and is thus an important mediator of the blood-retinal barrier breakdown leading to vascular leakage and macular edema. Therefore, anti-VEGF therapy is an effective therapeutic modality targeting the underlying pathogenesis of macular edema in RVO. Consequently, anti-VEGF intravitreal therapy has become the standard of care for treating macular edema.

Panretinal photocoagulation is th treatment of choice for neovacularisation of iris(NVI) or neovascular glaucoma(NVG) that develops as a complication of CRVO.

choices.text: The coefficient of variation of mean cell area is the most sensitive index of corneal endothelial dysfunction
Hexagonality is a good index of progress of endothelial wound healing
The corneal endothelial cell density declines throughout life at an average rate of 6%/year
This is the vital layer of the cornea

questions.text: Regarding the corneal endothelium, which of the following is the false statement?
questions.solution: Corneal endothelial density decreases at the rate of 0.6% per year.

questions.text: Which of the following may be injected intracamerally to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The arrow points to NeoVascularisation of Iris (NVI)

There are recent studies where intracameral injection(into the anterior chamber - aqueous) of anti-VEGF agents have been tried to manage early stages of NVI.

Conbercept and aflibercept are anti-VEGF drugs that are recombinant fusion proteins. They one block not only all VEGF-A isoforms but also VEGF-B and placental growth factor (PGF). Thus, they potentially have a much higher anti-VEGF effect than monoclonal IgG antibodies.

questions.text: CAIRS is used in the management of:
questions.solution: CAIRS, or Corneal Allogenic Intrastromal Ring Segments refers to mid-peripheral intrastromal transplantation of donor cornea stromal segments in patients with keratoconus.

choices.text: Specular microscopy of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy showing guttae
AS-OCT of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy showing guttae
Specular microscopy of PPMD showing duplicated Descemet's membrane
Specular microscopy showing lesions of Meesman's dystrophy

questions.text: The following images depict:
questions.solution:
Image A shows slit-lamp image - focussing on the endothelium with central corneal guttae

Image B shows specular microscopy showing the guttae characteristically seen in FUCH'S ENDOTHELIAL DYSTROPHY

choices.text: These are symptomatic amelanocytic iris hamartomas
These are asymptomatic amelanotic iris hamartomas
These are asymptomatic melanotic iris hamartomas

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the given image?
questions.solution:
These are Lisch nodules of NF-1. Lisch nodules are asymptomatic melanotic iris hamartomas. They are hyperplasia of iris pigment epithelium

They have a smooth, dome-shaped appearance and are usually light brown.

They develop during childhood, after the appearance of cafe-au-lait spots but before peripheral neurofibromas and so may be useful in confirming the diagnosis of NF1 in children with no family history and only multiple cafe-au-lait spots.

They are highly specific for NF1 and are present in over 90% of affected adults.

questions.text: All of the following are possible ocular findings in this child except:
questions.solution:
This is a case of Sturge Weber syndrome.

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is one of the phakomatoses. SWS, also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis includes leptomemeningeal hemangioma, facial angiomatosis or nevus flammeus (also called port-wine stain [PWS]), and ocular pathological changes.

The ocular findings seen in SWS are dilated episcleral vessels, congenital glaucoma, secondary open glaucoma(due to raised episcleral venous pressure), iris heterochromia, diffuse choroidal hemagiomas.

Option D is seen in NF-1

choices.text: This could be either AION or optic neuritis
Optic neuritis may precede the classical pulmonary manifestations of COVID-19
Optic neuritis may be unilateral or bilateral
In case of optic neuritis, CSF findings are found to be normal on doing lumbar puncture

questions.text: A patient admitted for COVID19 infection complained of sudden painless decrease in vision in his right eye. His pupillary reflex is abnormal. Fundus image is shown below. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
The image shows hyperemic disc edema which may be seen with AION or optic neuritis. COVID19 has been shown to cause AION and optic neuritis. CSF findings are abnormal in case of optic neuritis in COVID19-positive patients.

The other posterior segment associations are CRAO, CRVO.

The most common ocular manifestation of COVID19 infection is conjunctivitis(acute follicular conjunctivitis)

questions.text: A 53-year-old female reported to the eye OPD with c/o bilateral sudden painless decrease in vision. VA was 6/12 (OU). OCT of both eyes showed similar finding (as in the image). She was started on Trametinib/Dabrafenib for cutaneous melanoma 3 months ago. What does this image show and which drug is the cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of MEKAR - MEK inhibitor-Associated Retinopathy

Trametinib is a MEK inhibitor that is used in the treatment of cutaneous melanoma.

The ocular side effects of MEK-inhibitors are:

  1. Multifocal serous retinal detachment(CSR-like but multifocal)
  2. Cystoid macular edema
  3. Retinal venous occlusion

questions.text:
Denervation Hypersensitivity explains which of the following?
1. Constriction of Adie's pupil to 0.125% pilocarpine
2. Dilatation of Horner's pupil to 1% Apraclonidine
3. Dilatation of Horner's pupil to 4% cocaine
4. Constriction of normal pupil to phenylephrine
questions.solution:
Denervation hypersensitivity occurs due to upregulation of receptors.

  1. In Adie's pupil, due to upregulation of muscarinic receptors, the pupil constricts to 0.125% pilocarpine.
  2. In Horner's syndrome, due to upregulation of alpha-1 receptors, the pupil dilates to 0.5% or 1% Apraclonidine eyedrops

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with IOP of 32mmHg in her right eye. On examination of the optic disc, the CDR was 0.70. She underwent the procedure shown in the image. Gonioscopy shows 270 degrees PAS. What are the predictors of progression of the disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of PACG - Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma that has not been controlled even after laser peripheral iridotomy



PACG - factors for progression:

  1. Higher presenting IOP (>21 mm Hg; 32 mm Hg in this case)
  2. Larger Cup:Disc Ratio(CDR)
  3. Greater extent of Peripheral Anterior Synechiae (more than 180 degrees; 270 degrees in this case)

questions.text: Which of the most common ocular finding in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
• Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies (AChR-Abs) are present in up to 99% of patients with generalized myasthenia and 40-77% of patients with ocular MG.
  • AChR-Abs decrease the number of available AChRs by:
  1. receptor blockade
  2. complement-mediated membrane damage and
  3. accelerated degradation of the receptors

This results in defective transmission at the neuro-muscular junction and subsequent muscle weakness.

  • Variable ptosis is one of the most common manifestations of myasthenia gravis. It may be unilateral or bilateral– in bilateral cases, it is often asymmetrical.
  • Lid fatigability test - Ptosis increases with prolonged upgaze
  • Cogan's lid twitch: When the patient looks from downgaze to primary position, there is a quick overshooting upward movement followed by a down-drift of the upper lid.

Lagophthalmos is incomplete lid closure on attempted closing, due to facial nerve palsy or massive proptosis



Proptosis: Forward protrusion of the eyeball



Exophthalmos is proptosis due to thyroid eye disease

Lid retraction is the most common ocular finding of thyroid eye disease

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Roth spots are white-centered retinal hemorrhages. They are seen in:

  • Infective endocarditis
  • Anemic retinopathy
  • Leukemic retinopathy
  • Dengue retinopathy
  • Septicemia

choices.text: Extended treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
Emergency treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
Emerging treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
Early treatment for diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: ETDRS chart is used for recording visual acuity. What does ETDRS stand for?
questions.solution:
ETDRS stands for Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study.

Two commonly used tools for testing visual acuity in both the clinical and research setting include the Snellen and the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) VA charts

The Snellen chart, used chart for measuring visual acuity, consists of letters whose size is determined by the visual angle they occupy. The main drawbacks of this chart include the following:

  1. Different rows have significantly different number of characters ranging from 1-8 characters per row
  2. Inconsistent decrease in letter size from one row to the next
  3. Not all presented characters are equally legible

The ETDRS chart was introduced in the 1980s following recognition of the significant limitations of the Snellen chart, especially so in the low VA range. The main improvements incorporated into the ETDRS chart include:

  1. Equal number of characters per row
  2. Equal logarithmic decrement between successive rows
  3. Use of character types which are of relatively uniform legibility

choices.text: It has a definite association with M.tuberculosis
ATT may be given for 9 months
Vitrectomy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 28 year old healthy guy presents with sudden painless of vision in his left eye. He says that this is the third episode in the past year.On DDO, there are black spots amidst the red reflex. Fundus image is shown below. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Eales' disease is an idiopathic inflammatory venous occlusive disease. It primarily affects young adult males and is often bilateral.

It is characterized by three overlapping stages:

  1. peripheral venous inflammation (vasculitis) - type 3 hypersensitivity
  2. occlusion and
  3. retinal neovascularization

Diagnosis is mostly clinical and requires exclusion of other systemic or ocular conditions that could present with similar retinal features.

Recurrent vitreous haemorrhage is the hall mark of Eales' disease.

Vitreous bleeds produce the dark spots on Distant Direct Ophthalmoscopy(DDO).

Treatment is usually:

  • Corticosteroids in the inflammation stage
  • Photocoagulation in the proliferative stage of the disease

Visual prognosis is good if treated early in the course of the disease.

Empirical ATT is given for 9 months. The ATT protocol is usually reserved for patients with acute phlebitis with massive infiltration, nodule formation, and complete obliteration of segments of the vein.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female presented to the oculoplastics clinic with biopsy-proven basal cell carcinoma of the right periorbital region causing significant cicatricial ectropion of the right lower eyelid. The medial canthal lesion involved nearly the entire right lower eyelid with extension onto the cheek, the medial half of the right upper eyelid, the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva, as well as the right lacrimal system. CT imaging was suggestive of involvement of the extraocular muscles and other post-septal tissues. Fortunately, the patient had no metastatic disease. The extent of the tumor would have necessitated aggressive resection to achieve surgical cure. However, the patient preferred to attempt globe-sparing therapy with a goal of preserving cosmesis as much as possible. Which of the following drugs may be tried in this patient?
questions.solution:
Vismodegib  is a synthetic, small-molecule inhibitor of SMO(Smoothened Homologue) approved by the FDA in 2012 for treatment of locally advanced and metastatic Basal Cell Carcinoma

Guidelines for inoperability based on the tumor, node, and metastasis classification scheme have been proposed by the American Joint Committee on Cancer for eyelid carcinoma. The panel recommends that “eyelid tumors of stages T3a (defined as a tumor >20mm in greatest dimension, or any tumor that invades adjacent ocular or orbital structures, or any tumor with perineural tumor invasion), T3b, and T4 not appropriate for radical local therapy be assessed for possible systemic therapy with vismodegib, given 150mg orally daily.

The most common location of periocular BCC is medial canthus followed by lower lid

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Atropine?
questions.solution:
Atropine is a parasympatholytic. Hence, it causes paralysis of:

  • ciliary muscle producing loss of accommodation
  • sphincter pupillae producing passive dilatation of pupil(due to overaction fo dilator pupillae)

Pilocarpine is a parasympathomimetic that induces myopia. Therefore, it is contraindicated in young myopes.

questions.text: Risk factor for progression of glaucoma
questions.solution:
Disc findings that are risk factors of progression of glaucoma:

  • Higher CDR
  • Disc hemorrhages (in normal tension glaucoma)
  • Beta zone peripapillary atrophy

choices.text: Size of the lesion determines the prognosis
Gain of function mutation of BAP1 gene portends a poor prognosis
Epitheloid morphology on histopathology is associated with poor prognosis

questions.text: A 55-year old female came with complaints of metamorphopsia and decreased vision. After indirect ophthalmoscopy, the ophthalmologist performed ultraspund of the eye to decide the treatment modality. Ultrasound image is shown below. All of the following statements regarding her diagnosis are true except:
questions.solution:
This image shows choroidal melanoma with adjacent serous retinal detachment

The tumor has a collar-stud or mushroom appearance on USG, which is virtually pathognomonic



The glutamine (Q) 209 residue of GNAQ or GNA11 is frequently mutated in uveal melanomas (76.7% of primary uveal melanomas and 78.2% of metastatic uveal melanomas)

Monosomy 3 is a significant cytogenetic risk factor for aggressive uveal melanomas with poor prognoses.The BAP1 tumor suppressor gene is found on chromosome 3p21.1 and encodes a deubiquitinase enzyme. Somatic inactivating mutations of BAP1 are frequently found in metastatic uveal melanomas.

Histopathologic features of uveal melanomas associated with poor prognosis include

  • Epithelioid morphology
  • Intratumoral vascular 'loops'
  • Tumor size

Ocular or oculodermal melanoses are well-recognized risk factors for the development of uveal melanoma in Caucasian populations. Ocular melanosis (melanosis confined to the conjunctiva and uvea) and oculodermal melanosis (ocular melanosis with cutaneous involvement) are congenital conditions characterized by abundant melanocytes that present as uveal hyperpigmentation, conjunctival melanosis, and nevus of Ota.

questions.text: Which of the dye is used commonly in macular surgeries?
questions.solution:
Brilliant blue green dye(BBG) is used in macular surgery for internal limiting membrane(ILM) peeling.

Dyes in ophthalmology

  • Trypan Blue: Anterior Capsule staining in cataract surgery; also to stain Descemet’s membrane during DSEK(Descemet’s membrane Stripping Endothelial Keratoplasty)
  • Fluorescein: To stain epithelial defect
  • Rose Bengal: Staining devitalized epithelial cells
  • Alcian blue: Macular dystrophy(mucopolysaccharides)
  • Masson trichome: Granular dystrophy(Hyaline)
  • Brilliant blue green(BBG): To stain ILM

questions.text: A seven-year-old boy presented with difficulty in night vision of five years duration. Vision was 20/20 OU. Fundus examination revealed a golden sheen over the posterior pole in both eyes which disappeared after 45 minutes of dark adaptation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Oguchi's disease is an autosomal recessive form of congenital stationary night blindness and is caused by a disruption in the steps of inactivation of rod phototransduction.

Patients with this disease often complain of static nyctalopia since childhood and a preservation of vision in bright light. Rhodopsin kinase (GRK1) and Arrestin (SAG) are two genes which act in sequence to deactivate rhodopsin to stop the phototransduction cascade. Mutations in either the rhodopsin kinase gene or the arrestin gene cause a recessive form of stationary night blindness called Oguchi's disease.

The distinctive feature of Oguchi's disease is  golden-sheen fundus in the light-adapted state which normalises after prolonged dark adaptation. Again, it changes to the golden hue after a few minutes in the light. The colour change is called Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon. It is speculated to be the result of elevated extracellular potassium levels generated in the retina in response to an excessive stimulation of rod photoreceptors

questions.text: All of the following drugs may cause uveitis except:
questions.solution:
Drugs causing uveitis:

  • Cidofovir
  • Rifabutin
  • Bisphosphonates
  • Sulfonamides
  • Brimonidine
  • Metipranolol
  • Bevacizumab/Ranibizumab

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has been performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Evisceration is the removal of the eye's contents, leaving the scleral shell and extraocular muscles intact

Peritomy is cutting open the conjunctiva

questions.text: What is the visual field defect that would occur in case of lesion in the area marked in the image?
questions.solution: The area that is marked is the right Meyer's loop, containing the superior fibres of the optic radiation passing through the temporal lobe of the brain. Hence, lesion of this it would produce a 'contralateral homonymous pie-on-the-floor' visual field defect. Therefore, answer is left homonymous inferior quadrantanopia

choices.text: This patient has ocular hypertension that needs to be treated
His optic disc changes are suggestive of higher risk of progression to POAG
Central corneal thickness of the right eye is a risk factor for progression to POAG
Family history confers a risk factor of progression to POAG

questions.text: A 35-year old -2D myopic male with a family history of glaucoma came to the eye OPD for a routine refraction follow-up. On examination, his IOP was 25mm Hg and 21 mm Hg in the right and left eyes respectively; pachymetry readings were 550 microns and 580 microns respectively. The fundus images of both eyes are as shown. The visual fields were normal. Which of the following statement is true about this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of OCULAR HYPERTENSION

Ocular hypertension has been defined by:

  • Corrected intraocular pressure (IOP) higher than 21 mm Hg
  • Normal optic nerve and
  • Normal visual field

Optic discs shown in the images are normal.

An IOP of 26 mm Hg or more confers a higher risk of progression to POAG and may warrant initiation of treatment, in the presence of other risk factors. For an IOP of 25 mm Hg, anti-glaucoma drugs need not be started.

The 5-factor model for predicting progression of OHT to POAG:

  1. Higher Age
  2. Increased IOP(26mmHg or more)
  3. Pachymetry <555 microns (question says 550 microns in the right eye)
  4. Larger CDR
  5. Increased PSD(Pattern Standard Deviation) on visual fields
    • Family history is an independent risk factor for development of POAG. It is not a risk factor for OHT progressing into POAG

questions.text: The image shows the eye finding in a 3-month old breast-fed infant. Which enzyme is deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The image shows the 'oil droplet' cataract seen in galactosemia.

Galactosemia is a rare autosomal recessive condition caused by one of the three defective enzymes involved in galactose metabolism:

  1. Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT)
  2. Galactokinase
  3. Epimerase

Cataract occurs due to the accumulation of galactitol in the crystalline lens, particularly the nucleus. It is reversible in the early stages on cessation of lactose and galactose in the baby's diet.

questions.text: Zepto is used to:
questions.solution:
Zepto (trade name) is a novel capsulotomy technology called precision pulse capsulotomy (PPC). It is an FDA-approved disposable capsulotomy device that uses highly focused, quick, multi-pulse, low electrical energy discharge to produce a perfectly round anterior capsulotomy instantaneously uniformly along 360. It works independent of pupil size, corneal clarity, or lens density. This can be done during the normal sequence of the cataract surgery

Electrical nano-pulses are delivered to a nitinol (Nickel-Titanium) ring to create the capsulotomy instantaneously and simultaneously along all 360°, with no cautery or burning of tissue. Vaporization of water molecules trapped between the capsule and nitinol edge causes the stretched capsular membrane to split circumferentially all at once.

questions.text: Second order neurons are situated in which of the retinal layers?
questions.solution:
• First order neuron - Photoreceptors
  • Second order neuron - Bipolar cells
  • Third order neuron - Ganglion cells
  • Fourth order neuron - Lateral Geniculate Body

In the image of retinal layers:

  1. Ganglion cell layer
  2. Inner nuclear layer(containing cell bodies and nuclei of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, amacrine cells and Muller cells)
  1. Outer nuclear layer(containing cell bodies and nuclei of photoreceptors)
  2. Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE)

questions.text: A patient presented with right head tilt and right hypertropia. On right gaze, the right hypertropia increased. Which of the following muscles is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
On doing Park's three step:

First step:

questions.text: The given image shows:
questions.solution: Intercalary staphyloma is defined as ectasia(bulging) of the limbus(or within 2 mm of the limbus) and lined by root of the iris.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about this patient?
questions.solution:
This image shows subluxation of the lens.

The patient would complain of uniocular diplopia. Iridodonesis may be seen on examination. If zonules are missing/broken over a larger area, then it would not be possible to implant the IOL inside the capsular bag. In that case, CTRs(Capsular Tension Rings) may be used to stabilise the bag or Scleral-Fixated IOL(SF-IOL) may be implanted.

questions.text: 36-year-old patient with AIDS, CD4 count of 29 cells/mm3, recently placed on HAART therapy with presented with progressive decrease in visual acuity in the right eye for the past 6 months. On examination, large creamy to yellowish-white granular areas with perivascular exudates and hemorrhages were seen in the fundus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CMV retinitis is the most common opportunistic ocular infections of patients with AIDS. It occurs primarily in patients with CD4 T-lymphocyte counts of 50 cells/mm3 or less.

Key to effective treatment is the improvement of the immune status of the patient, especially institution of multidrug anti-HIV therapy for the HIV+ patient. In this patient, the recent initiation of HAART has not had sufficient time to build up the immunity and the CD4 cell count.

Most common ocular finding of HIV retinopathy is cottonwool spots. Differentiating suspected CMV retinitis from cotton wool spots is essential. Cotton wool spots appear as small, fluffy white lesions with indistinct margins and are not associated with exudates or hemorrhages.

questions.text: This test is used to
questions.solution:
Test For Stereopsis:

  1. The TNO stereo test
  2. Lang Stereotest II(random dot)
  3. Frisby Stereo Test
  4. Titmus Fly Test(Polaroid vectograph) - The right side of the test booklet contains a large housefly to test gross stereopsis. It is especially useful in young children. They are asked to pick up one of the wings of fly.

questions.text: The image depicts:
questions.solution:
Both the focal lines are behind the retina. Hence it is COMPOUND HYPERMETROPIC ASTIGMATISM

Vertical focal line is focussed ahead of the horizontal focal line. This means that the horizontal meridian(which produces the vertical focal line) is steeper.

When horizontal meridian(180 degrees) is steeper, it is against-the-rule astigmatism

choices.text: This condition may present with area postrema syndrome
PLEX should be considered early in the management of this condition

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with of sudden onset left eye pain followed by diminished vision. He also has tingling and weakness of right upper and lower limbs. Past history revealed the patient had nausea, hiccups, and epigastric pain, 4 months ago. A week later, he started to develop tingling sensation over his right upper limb. This persisted for nearly five weeks without the development of any other symptoms. Then, the tingling sensation progressed to involve the right lower limb. The tingling sensation was eventually followed by weakness in both right upper and lower limbs. The weakness in his right upper limb progressed to his right lower limb within a day and, thereafter, remained static. No history of weakness or sensory disturbances involving the left upper and lower limbs. There was no history of bowel or bladder incontinence. There was no history of fever, loss of consciousness, seizure, altered sensorium, or neck rigidity. He did not have any history of alcohol intake or tobacco smoking. There was also no history of any chronic medical illness. Which of the following statements regarding this patient is false?
questions.solution:
This patient has optic neuritis, myelitis and area postrema syndrome and is a case of NMOSD – NeuroMyelitis Optic Spectrum Disorder

NMO is severe immune-mediated inflammatory demyelinating disease and is predominantly characterized by the combination of optic neuritis and myelitis. Optic neuritis and area postrema syndrome may precede the development of myelitis in a case of NMO.

Aquaporin-4 is the target antigen in NMO and autoantibodies are found against this.

NMO has been reported to occur in association with mumps, acute infectious mononucleosis, varicella zoster virus, pulmonary tuberculosis, and syphilis.

NMO is an inflammatory CNS disorder distinct from multiple sclerosi. It is highly important to distinguish NMO from MS because the clinical course of NMO is more severe as compared to MS and the treatment is also different from MS. interferon-β, natalizumab, and fingolimod may even worsen the course of NMO.

PLEX (Plasma Exchange) therapy has been found to be very useful in the management of NMOSD

Biologics in NMOSD management:

Rituximab is a murine/human chimeric mAb against CD20 that is expressed on both immature and mature B lymphocytes.

Inebilizumab is a humanized IgG1 mAb against CD19 expressed on B lymphocytes

Satralizumab is a humanized IgG2 mAb targeting IL-6R

questions.text: What is the underlying principle behind this test?
questions.solution:
Duochrome test is based on Chromatic aberration - the shorter wavelengths (green) are focused in front of the longer red wavelengths.

It is used to refine the final sphere during refraction testing

questions.text: What does D represent in the image?
questions.solution:
A – Muller's muscle ( innervated by sympathetics)

B – Tarsal plate (fibrous tissue)

C – Meibomian gland (modified sebaceous gland)

D – Gland of Zeis (modified sebaceous gland)

Gland of Wolfring (accessory lacrimal gland) is present on thefree border of tarsal plate, on the palpebral conjunctiva

Gland of Henle is present at the limbus

questions.text: Which of the conditions violate Hering's law?
questions.solution:
• Dissociated Vertical Deviation(DVD) violates Hering's law of equal innervation to yoke muscles
  • Duane's retraction syndrome violates Sherrington's law of reciprocal inhibition of ipsilateral antagonist
